Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	So I therefore introduced a probe into one of the openings, and the probe reached to the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings and found that they were reaching into each other from all parts of the shin.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	So I approached and cut over one of those openings until I uncovered a part of the bone: and I found it corrupted, which was already eaten away, blackened, and rotten, and pierced through, until it reached to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore sawed what had been discovered for me, and prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I have ascertained that there is no lesion in the bone except for that corruption which I cut out and scraped.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed a restoration of the wound with consolidating medicines over a long period of time.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it has not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I attempted it again and laid a second dressing over the bone above the first discovery, and I found a continuous corruption with the bone, and I scraped out what appeared to me from that very corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	So I dressed it over him again, and did not cease to cut into the bone little by little, and try to restore it: and it was not restored, until I cut out from the bone about a hand's breadth, and extracted that with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines and it was consolidated quickly and healed, and this repetition of the operation on it and its section was not necessary, except because of the weakness of the infirm patient, and the scarcity of his tolerance, and my fear for him of death, since he would frequently fall into a bad condition from the excess evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	So he was healed with a complete recovery: and flesh hard as bone grew in the place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned to him: and he turned back to his natural dispositions: and there was no harm or discomfort in his walking whatever.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone is already broken in its place in the body: then it is necessary to saw it through, according to this manner: and thus: you will take a ligament and bind it at the end of the prominent bone: and have someone extend it upwards: and place another ligament made from thicker wool than the first one.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it above the flesh that is on the bone: and extend its end so as to draw the flesh downwards: and you will uncover the flesh over the place which you wish to saw, in order not to harm the saw.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a wooden splinter or a board under the lower bone in a proper manner, since when you do this it is not forbidden that spoiled flesh be cut.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that there be a cut above the spoiled place for a little while, so that spoilage of bone does not occur in concavity and does not appear in its appearance to sense, and forces another cut in its stead.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, that is, its part continues with a part, and corruption is in the middle of it or in its own part: then scrape away flesh from all parts entirely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a wooden splinter below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Next, cut it from the first part where is the corruption, until the cut continues from the other side; and be the cut second according to length from the corruption for a little while, as we said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	But if the corruption is at the joint, cut the very corrupted joint itself and cut the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if indeed corruption is in the conjunction of two joints, then there is no cure for it except scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if corruption is in the fleshy part of the hand or in the fleshy part of the foot: then the case with it is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Truly you must inquire into how corruption appears to yourself.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it away and clean it out as much as is possible for you to arrange, and with whatever skill corrects itself in your case: when it does not make a contradiction of Vein or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that scalpels and knives for cutting these bones are many, according to the situation of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherefore it is necessary that you prepare the proper instrument for every kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you about the shape of the instrument which you need, when with you is a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art is testimony to the methods of illnesses; then indeed you will find for yourself that which suits each one from instruments for every weakness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you will place as examples on which you will operate, and the proof by which you will experience with others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of a Serra.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another Serra.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of another Serra.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of another Serra. (same as previous)
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the Serra depicted, let it be accurately made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper arc be made sharp with iron and its handle from boxwood, and let it be pyramidal accurately made.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of a Razor for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this Razor be according to the shape of a star-headed awl's head and its points be according to the shape of the holes of an eschetic.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit, except that they are rubbed with it the heads of joints when they are corrupted or a large and big bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The shape of the larger Razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The shape of the middle Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The shape of the broad Razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape of the Razor with concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of another delicate Razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of another curved-edge Razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of a small, very fine Razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of the Razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape also of the large Razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a file and its end is like a saw: it is shown in many places from the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the razor that is suitable for its use on a perforated bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, with sharp points.
Fit ex Indi.	It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly all the things we have said should be made from razors, and knives, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On cutting extremities and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter Ninety-nine.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The limbs putrefy either from an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore when you have been treated for that corruption by medicines and the treatment does not help: and you see corruption falling into the limb which is not relieved by anything: then it is necessary to cut off that member as far as where the corruption follows, so that the infirm person may escape through it from death or a greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that it happens to him is, that the member blackens until it rots: which either fire burns or putrefies after blackening: until the rot is cut off as far as follows the member and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore act promptly with an incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the sting of certain venomous things, such as the sea scorpion, viper, and horned snake, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or sting is in an extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not give space to the corruption so that it may proceed into the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens to the hand, then cut off the hand from the wrist, and do not give space to the corruption until it reaches into the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades that, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however the corruption passes through and you see him around the elbow: then in that place is the death of the infirm person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer beyond that from treatment is quantity of power.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do the same for the foot, when corruption invades the toe, then cut it at one of its joints; and if it reaches into the heel of the foot, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	Which if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no art in it except for cutting off and leaving the sick person to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting a limb or sawing it is, to tie a string at the lower part which you wish to cut, and tie another string above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let the assistant stretch one cord below and the other cord above upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two cords with a spatula, until the whole flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut or sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth over all parts and the saw does not touch the healthy place; and an added wound should happen to the sick person and a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if bleeding occurs inside while you are operating, then burn the place quickly with a cautery; or put some powder on top which stops the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that which happened to a man on his foot, this same thing happening that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is, because a blackening occurred on his foot with burning which resembles the combustion of fire: and that corruption first happened in his toe, until it began to reach the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man cut out for himself after he saw the corruption invading the member with his madness which he found from pain and burning of it: and he cut it at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, it happened to him the same corruption in the index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came therefore to me, and I tried to recover the redundancy with him as I had put on his hand from medicines after purifying his body: and the redundancy was not restored, and began to spread into another finger: until corruption started in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called on me to cut off his hand and I refused, hoping for a recovery of that redundancy from me: and I also feared death in the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's power was greater than his condition.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	So therefore since he had despaired of me, he returned to his land and came back to me about him because he was urgent, and cut off his whole hand: and he healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account, unless it should be an aid for that which falls into the class of this illness: and so that it may be a sign by which it is understood, and according to which one acts.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas, and the quality of purgation with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in some fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or perforates, and what is within it comes out through the pus, and the place remains empty like a vessel: and the skin which is over it is like a cloth that has been worn thin: and it does not come to its ultimate corruption, nor presses into the bone, nor into the nerve, nor into the ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: but it is not called a Fistula: however if its space is prolonged until corruption presses into something of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or a Zunken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its cure is to cut into that skin all over as it blisters: and especially when it has been worn thin and made like a cloth: and trust that it will not adhere with the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If however you hope that the skin adheres, and the said corruption does not follow thereupon, and if there is a thickening of flesh on the skin, then treat it with a poultice: and it is, as if you should consider the arm pit.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then treat it with a poultice made from Egyptian medicine, which receives equal parts of vinegar, oil, and resin, that are gathered together in a vessel: and are heated over fire until the medicine becomes red: and it reaches the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey: and treat the armpit with a poultice made from it: and close its opening: and let the medicine remain in it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with a pressing: make it thus every day, until the armpit is cleansed and the stench is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is treated with ashes of wood when this medicine is not present to you: and it is, as if you should take the ash of vines' wood, or the ashes of ilex trees: and throw them over her.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then bind it up, and treat it with a poultice until you trust that the armpit is already washed clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	Which if the sick person is not tolerant of the Egyptian medicine, nor water and ashes, then treat it with a poultice made from water and honey to which something crushed from resin has been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or treat it with a poultice made from honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to cleanse and wash: and wine makes the armpit stick together, especially when there is an abundance of bitterness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do that several times and trust that the corruption of the armpit is already removed: then treat it with a poultice that makes flesh grow on it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And you should take from the diaphanismic plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil, and vinegar of the gallberry tree: or poultice it with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the sinus opening is tight and will not take a canula for poultice: then enlarge it with iron for a little while: or place a linen bandage wrapped around it in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment until it becomes enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also too large, then gather its lips together with a suture: and leave from it an amount into which it will enter a poultice without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening through which pus flows is elevated upwards: then cut it in a lower place that is in itself, so that the pus may flow from it downwards: because when the pus is shut up in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from forming in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus around its lower part as you wish: then try that you prepare the member with a preparation by which pus may flow from it easily, according to what has been prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try that nothing of the pus may remain in it at all: and take consolidating medicines which are placed on a sign, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size as to make communication with the entire sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors into a straight opening of the sinus an aperture, enlarging the sinus opening slightly.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread over another cloth a small quantity of soft ointment, according to the size of the aperture: and place it over it in such a position far from the sinus opening, so that the exit of pus from it may be alleviated: and you should not remove the large cloth until after several days one by one.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He, however, who is over the opening of the sinus, is he whom you remove every hour, so that what accumulates in it from pus may come out; and so that you may know whether what runs out of it is much or little, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, consider the place of the sinus itself, whether its lord feels pain in it or not; and whether there is an abscess in it, or there is not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is stretched thus and you see the material which runs out over the opening of the sinus, then know that the sinus already adheres or is approximating adhesion: then therefore loosen it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you have loosened the wound, then change another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if after a long space of time thin pus runs out from the sinus, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing approaches, because there are people who slow down the formation of flesh in their wounds and there are those who act against it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if after many days un-digested pus runs out from the sinus, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its matter prolonged: then add to the drying out medicines, but let the physicians see that they are wet in substance and dry in virtue: as diachylon ointment when superfluity of addition from resin is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the most ultimate thing by which it is cured, is that you take diachylon ointment and it is dissolved with rose oil, and wine of old vintage equal in substance to it is sprinkled over it.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it together with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it makes similar to this action when you do not have present diachylon ointment, honey, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloes and galbanum. Pound them altogether, and powder that on honey when it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread it on a cloth and tie it up in the chest. And smear with honey that you have cooked until thickened: and powder over it spices, and put it over a cloth and tie him.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with Aristolochia longa and roots of celestial lily and lily and flour of herb and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them either simple or compound, pound these things and sift them: and powder over honey which I have spoken of, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the swelling of the chest persists and does not heal with this treatment: then know that there is corruption within it; either already making a impression in the bones, or in other hard parts, or ligaments: then cure it with the cure of fistulas, according as was previously said.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Concerning the treatment of paronychia and a worn-out nail, and by cutting into an added finger and by section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Paronychia is an aposteme which is born under the nail of a hand or foot finger, and perhaps it also arises in the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the thing prolongs and its cure is neglected, and it apostemates with a hot aposteme: or it corrupts and lets out pus, until it corrodes the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption comes to the bone, so that there is a foul odor: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you cure it with what we said in the division, and your treatment does not help: then you must cut out with a knife the whole excess which remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	A cauterizing instrument is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if indeed the bone is sound and the nail also is healthy, and the additions of the nail already compress the flesh to the inside, and begin to pierce it, and hurt it: then you should place a subtle cautery under the angle of the nail that pierces the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut through the flesh with ease, and put over what remains of the flesh medicines that burn and corrode, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat that wound with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if corruption has already taken hold in the bone, then you must cut through that bone and remove it: for it is not healed ever while a corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	And if you see corruption and rot proceeding in the finger, then cut it off at one joint, according to what has been previously mentioned regarding its amputation.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat that, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if there should occur nail abrasion or blow, and it happens that a sharp pain accompanies it, then you must bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp stone knife, making an oblique incision from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful that the incision does not reach the flesh under the nail, for you will cause a severe pain to occur above it over the patient, and it will be a cause of an additional growth of flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat the place with what calms pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The added finger that grows on some hands of men, perhaps is entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail; and in some of them it grows at the root of the joint, or its growth occurs at some joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore that which grows in some joints of the finger does not move; and that which grows at the joint of the finger perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	His therefore who among them is fleshy, his section is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is, that you cut it near its root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But his whose birth is in the joining of roots, cure is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting into it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But he who is born in the finger near the last joints, then you must cut into his first flesh with a round incision to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw through the bone with one of those saws which are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then cure him until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the joining together of fingers which happens among them, often happens either from the birth of man, that is, it is born with him, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from burning by fire and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore you should cut off that joining until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen or cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate them; or put between them a thin lead plate, until the place is consolidated as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if there occurs a joining of some fingers with the palm, then cut off that joining, according to how it is prepared and suits the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ About the cutting of defect.
Caput XCII.	Chapter Ninety-Two.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins are swollen, thick, full of superfluous melancholic humors which occur in many parts of the body: and most often they happen in legs, especially in the legs of travelers and laborers, and carriers.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary to administer a body cleansing with black henna several times with strong scrubbing.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then let blood from the basilica vein of the patient.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these with iron is according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are scraped and the black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other mode is that the vein be raised and the entire thing be drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of it, however, is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	He binds the leg with a cloth soaked much in hot water until the thick and feculent blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then he tightens the leg of the invalid from the upper part of his hip to the lower part of the knee with a strap.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then one cuts the vein in one place or two or three places with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise, that is, draw out the blood from your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top and it should be necessary for the phlebotomist to cut the invalid first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then one cuts the nail down as far as possible until there escapes from the blood a quantity which you see is sufficient and which the strength of the invalid can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it and instruct him to abstain from foods generating black bile. And repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full and that thing harms the invalid.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The raising of it is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrape the leg of the invalid if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert him into a bath or bind him on the leg with hot water until he redden and the veins be swollen or exercise him in strong exercise if there is no bath available, until the member becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then one cuts the skin in a straight line through the length of the vein or at its end near the knee or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook and scrape out the vein from every part until it appears to sense and is apparent when you see that it reddens towards blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it goes out of the skin, you see it white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it a thread, until when it is elevated and goes out of the skin, suspend it with a black hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another section near that other section three fingers away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then remove the skin from the upper part of the vein, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with threads as you did, and suspend it with another hook, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut another section, or multiple sections, if you need them.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it and incise the very last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then draw it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you draw her out from the upper section, or all higher sections, until when she goes out entirely; then cut her.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if she does not obey you to be drawn out and elevated: then insert the needle with a strong thread doubled, and tie her, and draw it out; or insert under it threads: and turn your hand in every direction, until it goes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware that it does not cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it becomes difficult for you to elevate it greatly, and goes out on the patient from it a harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have drawn it out entirely: then put on the place of wounds a cloth dipped in wine and rose oil, or oil; and take care of him until he heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the vein is contracted, having a twisting which coils back to the parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then you must that you cut over it on all its twists, and places of its coiling.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks, until you elevate it entirely; and beware at your cut over it not to cut the vein, or wound: for it will be difficult for you to elevate, or draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of a wound in which it is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the closed fracture.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curved like the other fractures, nor is it an acute extremity so as to lacerate a vein; and it is a coarse flexibility, gentle; because if it were subtle, it would cut a vein by its subtlety: or rather let its grossness be in excess, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the removal of the vein of the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter Ninety-Three.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is produced in the legs of cold lands, such as Algeria, and the land of Arabs, and in dry hot lands with little tenderness, that is, in which there does not grow grass nor tree.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is produced in other places of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction which occurs under the skin, just as it happens in the bodies of serpents and Ascaride worms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's occurrence is that an intense inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place becomes swollen.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out from that place of swelling, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore its extremity appears from it, then you should wind a leaden fragment over it, the weight of which is from one to two drachmas, and tie it up with thread: and let the lead hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something comes out of it to the outer things, wrap that up in lead and tie it up.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it is prolonged very much, then cut off a part of it, and wind the remainder around.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it at its root until it has entirely come out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	If it festers, it constricts and penetrates into the flesh; and causes an apostema, and a rotting in the place, and an evil ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be treated gently and gradually removed until it comes out completely from the end of itself, and nothing remains of it in the body; and indeed from this vein some people discharge in its length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to my attention because a man discharged from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it festers on you during the hour of your treatment: then insert a thread into its opening and perforate it with a long needle, along with the body, until all that is in it is emptied out from matter; and administer corruption of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then cure the place with the treatment for apostems.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And indeed this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or on the foot itself; and there occur to it many openings, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So then cure it therefore just as we said in the division, and along with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Concerning the cutting into worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine affliction.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This affliction is called Bovine affliction in a certain land among us; on account of the fact that it frequently occurs to oxen, and it is a small worm one which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it runs through the entire body, ascending and descending; and is shown to sense at its walking from member to member, until it bursts wherever it bursts a place in the skin, and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the rotting of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and serpents, that is, earthworms, and roundworms occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And fear is incurred from its evilness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes into the body and rises to the head and reaches that place then perhaps it opens up there and comes out and destroys the eye and that often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	So when you wish to cure him and extract it then that does not happen except at his movement and appearance to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	You must therefore bind what is above it and what is below it with a strong constricting ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it and extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it sinks into the flesh and you cannot find it then put a cautery on top of the place with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And more to be feared is its corruption which corrupts the eye as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see it has already reached the head near the eye then bind a good bandage under it above the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient must use purification of his body with dissolving medicines for bad and putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods causing putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the operation for the pain of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This affliction is called in our land Nakir and it is a pain that occurs in some members then it changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen it as I am now telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm muscle.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed I saw a swelling move with speed, as if it were a worm, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than is possible: so that it might be like quicksilver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore receded from that place, and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and ran to the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was revolving in his entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I therefore marveled at the speed of its transformation from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed before that I had not seen this affliction with my own eyes in such a manner as this.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However I have seen many who find the pain to be transformed from member to member, and I did not see him with my own eyes as I saw her.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is otherwise than that it was because the woman was of those who are from dry bodies with detected veins; hence therefore it appears to the sense that this inflammation has been transformed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to treat him and the patient feels that pain as we said, then bind tightly above it and below it quickly; and cut above it until the inflamed swelling departs; and cautery the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then treat him by bloodletting and with that which drives out swellings; and cauterize them with pills of stinking pitch, and pills of opoponax, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	About the removal of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are distinguished according to their kinds and the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is that there are some which have large points and small ones, and concave and pointed.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them are needles.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those however which fall according to limbs, is according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For indeed limbs are from main convex parts, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and those similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	Therefore when it falls into some of these limbs, and death signs appear to you which I shall tell you next, then it is necessary that you avoid the extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when those evil signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then draw it out and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs of the brain when the arrow falls into it and penetrates the bone and exits through the suture which is above the brain, there are: because from it happen violent headache, and scotoma, and dizziness, and redness in the eyes, and swelling, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and mixture of intellect, and choleric vomiting.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will issue from the nostrils, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there issues from the place of the wound a white moisture similar to pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it comes out like the moistness of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and draw out the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left breast; and feels with it as if itself were fixed in a hard thing, not in an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow's movement is similar to the beating of the pulse; and blood black flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows that coldness of extremities, and a cool sweat, and stitches.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You should therefore know for certain that death is approaching.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow that wounds the lung is a foamy bleeding from the wound, and the vessels which follow the neck become inflamed and change in colour to those of the sick person.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And it exhales a large and deep breath, and seeks the inhalation of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the membrane that is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and a great panting occurs with severe pain and sighing; and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested will come out from the wound with food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly and sticks there, something will come out from the wound which is stool, or dung, or a intestine that has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for its cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out, and something proceeds from it to the outside, and a more severe pain is over the sick person, then you should know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	However, the other limbs, such as the face, and the neck, and the throat, and the ribcage, and the spine, and the hip, and the leg, and similar parts of the body are saluted according to many dispositions: when the arrow does not find the artery, or the nerve, and it is not a poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen about being of these arrows, so that you may signify by it over your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is, because an arrow fell into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore take it out from that other part itself under its ear fat; and it is healed, and no harm occurs to it.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I took another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his eye fat under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was now hidden, and I did not succeed with it except for a small part of it, which clung to its wooden shaft; and it was a large arrow among the arrows of Turkish bows, with a soft iron point, in which there is no ear.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was therefore healed, and no evil accident occurred to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I took another arrow out of the throat of the Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and it is that one to which there are ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore tied over it between two splints; and now it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I therefore carefully twisted with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I took out another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly; and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After therefore thirty days had passed over him, and nothing had changed for him from his conditions, I tied over the arrow; and I cleverly twisted over it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil accident occurred to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw the man on whom the arrow had fallen into his back, and the wound over it was consolidated.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After therefore seven years had passed, the arrow came out from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw the woman on whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound over it was consolidated, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing changed for her from her conditions, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man on whom an arrow had fallen into his face: and the wound was consolidated, and it remained, not finding much pain for him: and similar things to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man, the chief of the king's men, which had fallen into the middle of his nose and was now inclining to the right side somewhat; and the arrowhead was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called to heal him after the accident with the arrow until three days had passed.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found, therefore, the wound of the arrow to be very tightly closed.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I then questioned her with a slender probe and did not feel it; and she herself was finding a puncture and pain under her ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that that was the puncture from the point of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore applied a plaster to the place where I had confidence that an abscess would form and show me a sign of the arrow, so that I could cut over it; and it did not happen in the place where it occurred, which was a sign that the arrowhead had passed through.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore applied the plaster over him for many days; and no abscess occurred, and the wound became consolidated in the meantime; and he remained sick from its removal for a period of days, until on a certain day he felt the arrow within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	And so I put over that wound a sharp, corroding medicine for many days until it was open; and with probes I searched into it, and I felt the tip of the arrow fine and delicate which adhered to the bone.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound that sharp medicine until it appeared clearly to us the tip of the arrow; and besides this, a period of time of about four months passed with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert a forceps into it and move it, but it did not yield to exit; I then did not cease to refine and devise on it with every kind of device until one day I began over it with well-made forceps, according to how their shape will fit at the end of the arrowhead, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed physicians judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it and the wound was consolidated and the patient was healed completely with entire health and nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: that you place a rule and a guide over it, which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and its distinctions cannot be comprehended with a narrative: nor can that book comprehend it, and a prudent craftsman compares little to much: and what is present with him, over what is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument for the descent of foreign things in this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not exit from the limbs to which they are fixed, unless in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or contrary to the other part of it.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits from where it entered is either an arrow going into a fleshy place and is attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not comply to exit from the hour in which it falls: then you must let go of it for some days, until the flesh around it has putrified and its attraction is alleviated and its egression eased.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone and does not comply with you to exit, then let go of it also for some days: and try it every day with an attempt and motion until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	And if it does not comply with you to exit after days, then you must perforate around the arrow in the bone from all parts with a fine awl until the hole is widened.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull and has proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and certain of those symptoms which I mentioned appear from the patient: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and let it be until its condition becomes suitable after some days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if an arrow has reached the spleen, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in a bone of the body and does not penetrate as far as the spleen: and the invalid remains for several days and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then wisdom lies in drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is very firmly fixed and does not obey you to be drawn out: then apply tar in the vicinity of the arrow, as I told you before: then treat the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already hidden in a place of the body and is concealed and hidden from sense: then seek it out with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for its removal.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot reach it because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow in depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then make a cut over it, until the wound becomes enlarged, and it becomes possible to draw out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	And if there are ears to which it is fixed: then free the fixed flesh from them on all sides, with every artifice by which you can do that, and use art, if you cannot reach the egress of the flesh in the breaking of the ears and their twisting, until it escapes.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.
